channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: ‘They Are Gone, Vanished’: Missing Persons Haunt Ukrainian Village
item.description: In a Russian-occupied village, five men went off to feed cattle. Their relatives and neighbors are wondering what happened to them.
item.media:description: A cellar in Husarivka, Ukraine. At least three skulls were recovered there earlier this month.

item.title: Rare Overlap of Holy Days Shows Jerusalem’s Promise and Problems
item.description: In its Old City, a Christian, a Jew and a Muslim marked Easter, Passover and Ramadan. To some, it’s a “symphony.” To others, a reminder of division.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: A view of the Old City of Jerusalem on Thursday, the eve of the first convergence of the three holidays since 1991.

item.title: Live Updates: Ukraine’s Last Troops in Mariupol Hold On as Russia Demands Surrender
item.description: Gaining control of the southern port city would help Russia complete its coveted “land bridge” to occupied Crimea. Moscow struck military targets around Kyiv and Mykolaiv, in apparent retaliation for Ukraine’s sinking of a Russian warship.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A barrage of rockets slammed into central Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday, setting fire to apartment buildings and a market.

item.title: Yemen’s Houthis Went From Ragtag Militia to Force Threatening Gulf Powers
item.description: Iran’s cultivation of the Houthis over the years of war in Yemen has armed them with missiles and drones, endangering Washington’s partners and Tehran’s rivals, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard
item.media:description: Security forces for the Houthi rebels in March in Sana, Yemen.

item.title: The World’s Broken Promise of Asylum
item.description: Britain’s new plan to send thousands of asylum seekers to Rwanda exposes the fragile nature of the global refugee compact, which has always fallen prey to domestic politics.
item.dc:creator: Max Fisher
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Britain’s Border Force taking refugees to Dover, England, last year after picking them up in the English Channel.

item.title: Israeli Police Stop Muslim Worshipers From Entering Holy Site
item.description: Brief clashes broke out Sunday after the Israeli police blocked Muslim access to the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as Temple Mount, in order to prevent contact between Palestinians and Jewish visitors.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:description: Israeli security forces patrolling on Sunday near the Aqsa Mosque compound, known to Jews as the Temple Mount.

item.title: Putin’s Ukraine Gamble Pivots to a Very Different Battlefield
item.description: After Russian forces were mauled in cities and towns in northern Ukraine, Vladimir V. Putin is shifting the focus of his invasion to the flatlands of Donbas, in the east.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier in February in Trokhizbenka, in the Luhansk region.

item.title: War in Ukraine Has Left Eastern Europe Sleepless
item.description: Mental health professionals across the region say they have seen an increase in patients with intense anxiety. Some are asking for more sleeping pills, and many are making escape plans.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Ukrainian and Polish flags projected on a building last month in Warsaw. The suffering of the millions of refugees from Ukraine in the region is a constant reminder of how real — and how close — the war is.

item.title: Kashmir Journalists Face Forbidding Pattern: Arrest, Bail, Rearrest
item.description: The practice, employed against at least three journalists in the restive region, is being used to limit free speech and chill news reporting, activists say.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:credit: Saqib Majeed/SOPA Images/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Aasif Sultan, a journalist in Kashmir, when he was first detained by the Indian authorities in 2018.

item.title: Telegram: Where Russians Turn for Uncensored Ukraine News
item.description: Telegram is the platform of choice for Russians seeking to escape Moscow’s propaganda web. But can it last?
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova, Neil MacFarquhar and Adam Satariano
item.media:description: The Moscow subway in February. Russia has silenced independent news media and banned social media platforms like Twitter, Facebook and Instagram.

item.title: Why Ukraine War Crimes Trials Could Take Many Years
item.description: Long after the fighting ends, any prosecutions and trials arising from it could be barely beginning. Here is a look at the complexities of bringing aggressors to justice.
item.dc:creator: Rick Gladstone and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A building in Borodianka, Ukraine, that was heavily damaged in a Russian attack this month.

item.title: Jerusalem Tattoo Artist Inks Pilgrims, Priests and Those Scarred by Conflict
item.description: For Wassim Razzouk, Holy Week is his busiest time as Christians seek a reminder of their visit to Jerusalem. But his family’s centuries-old tattoo business caters to all faiths.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Amit Elkayam for The New York Times
item.media:description: Wassim Razzouk, left, working on a tattoo for Kathryn O’Brien, a student from Texas. Some visitors to Jerusalem “want a tattoo as a certificate of pilgrimage,” he said.

item.title: Faced With a Changed Europe, China Sticks to an Old Script
item.description: Europe was viewed as lacking the power and the will to contest China’s rise. But now, a harder line toward Russia has implications for Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Buckley and Keith Bradsher
item.media:description: At a video meeting on April 1 with European officials, China’s leader, Xi Jinping, made clear the country would not distance itself from Russia.

item.title: Tanzania’s First Female President Wants to Bring Her Nation in From the Cold
item.description: Samia Suluhu Hassan became the only female head of government in Africa when her predecessor suddenly died. She is setting a new course.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir
item.media:credit: Malin Fezehai for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Samia Suluhu Hassan of Tanzania this month at Chamwino State House in the capital, Dodoma.

item.title: Pope Speaks of Ukraine’s Suffering on ‘an Easter of War’
item.description: In his blessing to pilgrims, Pope Francis quoted a manifesto against nuclear weapons and said conflict in Europe should bring increased attention to violence around the world.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis greeting the faithful as he rode in his Popemobile through St. Peter's Square on Sunday.

item.title: Days After the Sinking of the Russian Warship, Moskva, Questions Linger
item.description: A talk-show host, who usually reflects the Kremlin’s line, questioned how the ship was lost.
item.dc:creator: Neil MacFarquhar
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Maxar Technologies showed the warship Moskva docked at a port in Sevastopol, Crimea, last week.

item.title: Worshipers Fill Pews in Lviv on Easter Sunday for Services That Remember War
item.description: Commemorations in Ukraine’s small Roman Catholic community combined ancient traditions with the reality of the war.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Communion at St. Anthony Church in Lviv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Pope Calls for Peace in Ukraine on What He Called ‘Easter of War’
item.description: Instead of learning from the heavy toll taken by the pandemic, and emerging with strengthened solidarity, rivalry had prevailed, the pope said.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis at the Vatican on Sunday.

item.title: A Violent Crisis
item.description: The Brooklyn shooting and other headline-making violence are part of a broader trend.
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Brittainy Newman for The New York Times
item.media:description: A police officer watches as people enter the 42nd Street Grand Central subway station in New York, after a mass shooting on a Brooklyn subway last week.

item.title: Fighting for Her Life, Far From Ukraine
item.description: A 5-year-old Ukrainian girl with a brain tumor was one of several children brought for treatment in the United States after their country was invaded by Russia.
item.dc:creator: Isadora Kosofsky and Miriam Jordan
item.media:credit: Isadora Kosofsky for The New York Times
item.media:description: Bogdan Kretsul, 8, and Khrystyna playing at Target House, a residential building where the families of children receiving treatment live.

item.title: North Korea Launches 2 Short-Range Missiles
item.description: The missile test, the North’s 12th of the year, took place as South Korea and the United States were preparing to begin joint military exercises.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:description: News coverage of North Korea’s missile test on a screen in a Seoul train station on Sunday.

item.title: Macron Vows Ambitious Green Policies, Wooing the Left in Runoff
item.description: France’s president is trying to tap into the country’s large pool of left-wing voters, but many are hesitant to back him.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France speaking at a campaign rally in Marseille on Saturday.

item.title: Israel Steps Up Raids in Palestinian Territories in Response to Attacks
item.description: At least 14 Palestinians have been killed in a widespread Israeli military operation in the West Bank, launched in response to a string of attacks in Israel that killed 14 people.
item.dc:creator: Raja Abdulrahim
item.media:credit: Samar Hazboun for The New York Times
item.media:description: Khuloud Zakarneh, the mother of 16-year-old Mohammad Zakarneh, who she says was shot and killed by Israeli forces, comforts her daughter Sedra in their home in the West Bank city of Jenin.

item.title: Russia Fires Missile Barrage at Ukrainian Cities and Military Targets
item.description: The strikes seemed aimed at hampering Ukraine’s war fighting capacity as the conflict shifts to eastern Donbas region, and at responding to the sinking of a Russian warship.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Marc Santora and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:description: A shopping center in central Kharkiv was struck by what appeared to be guided missiles on Saturday. Russian forces continue to strike cities across Ukraine.

item.title: What Will Happen if Russia Defaults on Its Debt?
item.description: The ultimate arbiter of a sovereign default is an open question but markets may have the final word.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.category: Credit Ratings and Credit Rating Agencies
Office of Foreign Assets Control (United States Treasury)
item.media:description: A debt default would be a stain on the economic stewardship of President Vladimir V. Putin.

item.title: Peng Ming-min, Fighter for Democracy in Taiwan, Dies at 98
item.description: He endured Japanese imperial rule, a lost limb in World War II, Chinese martial law and decades in exile to become a leading force for Taiwanese self-determination.
item.dc:creator: Chris Horton
item.media:description: Peng Ming-min delivering a speech in 1995, when he was running for president of Taiwan. He did not win, but his candidacy was a turning point in Taiwan’s democratic journey.

item.title: Moskva’s Sinking Inspires One of Ukraine’s Most Popular Rockers
item.description: Vadym Krasnooky, whose band Mad Heads had stopped performing when the war began, said his new song is meant to ‘channel all this hate.’
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: The Russian warship Moskva, sunk after being reportedly hit by Ukrainian missiles, has inspired a song by a popular Ukrainian rock star.

item.title: A Nazi Soldier Stole a Watch in 1942. It Turned Up 80 Years Later.
item.description: The watch, made as a gift in 1910, has been returned to the maker’s family in the Netherlands. It still works.
item.dc:creator: Claire Moses
item.media:description: The pocket watch includes an inscription on the back stating the maker’s name and the place and time it was made, as well as the fact that it was intended for his brother.

item.title: Meet the Hot New Houseplant
item.description: A new “It” plant is here, if you can keep it alive.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: In Quebec, the Clash Over Caribou Heats Up
item.description: Canada is threatening to use, for the first time, a provision in endangered species legislation to intervene and force caribou habitat protection in Quebec.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai

item.title: India Is Stalling the W.H.O.’s Efforts to Make Global Covid Death Toll Public
item.description: The agency has calculated that 15 million people have died as a result of the pandemic, far more than earlier estimates, but has yet to release those numbers.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen and Karan Deep Singh
item.media:credit: Atul Loke for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mass cremation in New Delhi during a devastating Covid surge in April 2021.

item.title: As Russia Pivots East, Ukrainians Ask: Are We Next?
item.description: Our cameras captured life on the front lines in southeast Ukraine, where Russian shelling is relentless and it feels like the war is inching closer every day.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Mark Boyer and Benjamin Foley
item.media:credit: Benjamin Foley for The New York Times

item.title: Moskva, Russia’s Prized Ship, Was Hit by Missiles, U.S. Officials Say
item.description: The sinking of the Moskva was a major blow to the Russian fleet and the most significant combat loss for any navy in decades.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and James Glanz
item.media:description: The Moskva in 2014. The vessel’s sinking has symbolic, diplomatic and military importance.

item.title: Girding for New Battle, Russia Warns U.S. on Advanced Weapons for Ukraine
item.description: The warnings were regarded as a sign that American military assistance to Ukraine was compounding problems for the Russians in their two-month-old invasion.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Helene Cooper and Anton Troianovski
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sister Diogena Tereshkevych comforting people displaced from eastern Ukraine while inside a bomb shelter during an air raid alert in the western Ukrainian city of Lviv on Friday.

item.title: Biden Plans to Open More Public Land to Drilling
item.description: The president is under pressure to bring down gas prices, but any new drilling would be years away. The fees that companies pay would rise sharply.
item.dc:creator: Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Brandon Thibodeaux for The New York Times
item.media:description: A pump jack in Texas in 2019. As a candidate for president, Mr. Biden promised “no more drilling on federal lands.”

item.title: Ukrainians Detail the Terror Russian Soldiers Have Inflicted Near Kyiv
item.description: An ordeal at a mental health facility in Ukraine illuminated the horrors of the Russian occupation in the areas around Kyiv.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Oleksandr Chubko and David Guttenfelder
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Ukrainians cleaning out an employment office in the devastated town of Borodianka, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Days After Ouster, Imran Khan Is Back on the Trail in Pakistan
item.description: With fiery critiques of his rivals and the U.S., the former prime minister has drawn thousands to rallies across Pakistan and stoked fears of more political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Salman Masood and Ihsanullah Tipu Mehsud
item.media:description: Imran Khan, who was forced to step down as prime minister this week, during a rally on Wednesday in Peshawar, Pakistan.

item.title: How Russian Media Uses Fox News to Make Its Case
item.description: The conservative network has appeared hundreds of times in Russian media.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson

item.title: Russia’s Sunken Warship Moskva Was Hit by Ukrainian Missiles, U.S. official says
item.description: Moscow claimed the sinking was an accident, but U.S. intelligence reports say the cruiser went down after Ukraine struck it with Neptune missiles.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:description: A satellite image released by Maxar Technologies showed the warship Moskva docked at a port in Sevastopol, Crimea, last week.

item.title: Families of U.K. Covid Victims React to Boris Johnson Fines
item.description: Those unable to be with dying loved ones find no satisfaction or closure with the penalty Prime Minister Boris Johnson faces for breaking lockdown rules.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson and Rishi Sunak, the chancellor of the Exchequer, in London in 2020. Both were fined for breaching pandemic lockdown laws.

item.title: What Boris Johnson’s Deal With Rwanda Means for U.K. Asylum System
item.description: Prime Minister Boris Johnson announced a plan to send some of those seeking refuge to the central African country. What effect would the change have?
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia
item.media:credit: Andrew Testa for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.K. Border Force cutter Vigilant bringing refugees into Dover last year after picking them up in the English Channel.

item.title: How Russian Disinformation Spreads Beyond Its Borders
item.description: A New York Times’ video team traveled to the breakaway region of Transnistria to find out what residents there believe about the war in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Simon Ostrovsky and Emily Rhyne
item.media:description: Emily Rhyne/The New York Times

item.title: Shanghai’s Isolation Facilities Have Prompted a Backlash
item.description: Hundreds of thousands of Shanghai residents have been sent to quarantine and isolation facilities. One woman described her ordeal.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson

item.title: Quiz Time on the Campaign Trail
item.description: Several “gotcha” questions for candidates, including one that Anthony Albanese got wrong, raise deeper questions about the quality of the nation’s political discourse.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:description: Anthony Albanese, the opposition leader, on the first day of the federal election campaign on Monday in Launceston, Australia.

item.title: Amazon vs. the Union
item.description: The company and its new union share the same problem.
item.dc:creator: Jodi Kantor and Karen Weise
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.media:description: Derrick Palmer, speaking during a protest outside a home belonging to Amazon’s founder, Jeff Bezos, in Manhattan in December 2020.

item.title: Russia’s loss of its Black Sea flagship would make capturing Odesa harder, analysts say.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: A satellite image from Maxar Technologies showed the warship Moskva docked at a port in Sevastopol, Crimea, last week.

item.title: What to Know About 2022 World Cup Travel to Qatar
item.description: Tickets are on sale for the world’s most popular sporting event, but concerns over worker exploitation and laws against homosexuality have complicated the decision to attend for some fans.
item.dc:creator: Jeff Z. Klein
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Tamir Kalifa for The New York Times
item.media:description: Javain Brown of Jamaica and Tim Weah of the U.S. men’s national soccer team during the 2022 World Cup qualifying match in Austin, Texas, in October. The U.S. team will return to the tournament after failing to qualify in 2018.

item.title: Military Memo Adds to Possible Interstellar Meteor Mystery
item.description: The U.S. Space Command seemed to confirm a claim that a meteor from outside the solar system had entered Earth’s atmosphere, but other scientists and NASA are still not convinced.
item.dc:creator: Joey Roulette
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Office of Science and Technology Policy
item.media:description: The comet 2I/Borisov, the second known interstellar visitor to our solar system, observed by the Very Large Telescope in Chile in 2019.

item.title: Journey to Transnistria: Inside Russia’s Disinformation Bubble
item.description: We traveled inside Transnistria, a Moscow-backed breakaway state in Moldova, to find out how Russia’s disinformation campaign stretches beyond its borders.
item.dc:creator: Simon Ostrovsky and Emily Rhyne
item.media:description: Emily Rhyne/The New York Times

item.title: Kim Jong-un Gives North Korean TV Anchor a Luxury Home
item.description: Ri Chun-hee, who delivers the news with a soaring, bombastic tenor, received a two-story apartment in a riverside complex from the country’s leader, apparently for her loyalty.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, and Ri Chun-hee at the new building in Pyongyang this week.

item.title: A reporter covering the war reflects on the legacy of the Holocaust.
item.description: In eastern Poland, perceptions of Russia and Ukraine are shaped by a traumatic past.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees arriving in Przemysl, Poland, from Odesa, Ukraine, last month.

item.title: Russia’s Storied Ballet Is Among the Casualties of War
item.description: Ballet has long been a symbol of Russian culture. Now it is becoming a symbol of Russian isolation.
item.dc:creator: Alex Marshall
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The star ballerina Olga Smirnova with Semyon Chudin at the Bolshoi Theater in Moscow in 2014.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: Obstacles to Russia’s assault on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: The Moskva sank. Ukraine said it had attacked the ship with missiles. Russia said a fire had broken out.

item.title: Gina McCarthy, Top Climate Adviser, Is Said to Be Planning Departure
item.description: Ms. McCarthy was tapped by President Biden to lead an ambitious domestic climate agenda. Associates say she is frustrated by the slow pace of progress.
item.dc:creator: Lisa Friedman and Coral Davenport
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: Gina McCarthy, the national climate adviser, at the White House last year.

item.title: Tensions Over the Ukraine War Deepen the Chill Near the North Pole
item.description: The war and the comments of a Russian diplomat have strained relations on an archipelago in Norway where Russians, Ukrainians and Norwegians have lived peacefully for decades.
item.dc:creator: Jeré Longman and Erin Schaff
item.media:description: Sergey Gushchin, the Russian consul general, inside the Russian Consulate in Barentsburg, Svalbard, part of a Norwegian archipelago.

item.title: Russia Hits Setbacks, as Flagship Sinks and E.U. Mulls Oil Ban
item.description: Ukraine said it hit a Russian warship in the Black Sea with its own missiles, a damaging blow to Moscow, symbolically and militarily, if its claim is confirmed.
item.dc:creator: Matina Stevis-Gridneff and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:description: The missile cruiser Moskva, the flagship of Russia’s Black Sea Fleet, photographed in the port of Sevastopol in 2011.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: Russia’s Flagship Sinks
item.description: Plus Elon Musk’s bid for Twitter and Britain’s plan to resettle asylum seekers … in Rwanda.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: David Guttenfelder for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Ukrainian survivor rode a bicycle past the ruins of the village of Andriivka, west of Kyiv, on Thursday.

item.title: British Militant Convicted for Role in Deaths of Americans
item.description: The verdict capped a two-week trial that featured the testimony of former captives who detailed relentless beatings, waterboarding and killings by an Islamic State cell known as the Beatles.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.media:description: El Shafee Elsheikh, a British member of the Islamic State, was tried in Alexandria, Va., on charges of conspiracy and hostage-taking.

item.title: Russian Media Falsely Claims Ukraine Atrocity Images Are Fake
item.description: Russians are being shown some of the same distressing imagery from the war as the rest of the world, but with a big twist.
item.dc:creator: Valeriya Safronova
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: In this picture taken by a photojournalist for The New York Times, volunteer cemetery workers loaded bodies into a truck in Bucha, Ukraine.
